During the 19th century there were repeated Cholera and Yellow Fever epidemics in US cities. Thus Frederick Law Olmsted (1822 –1903) as an urban landscape planner demonstrated best the necessity of outdoor natural areas. One of his design principles was “Planning or designs so that they promote both the physical and mental health of users.”[1] Without a routine, recurrent, and respectful use of outdoor recreation the human body and spirit shrink to the perishing point. But Olmsted described it well, after all he suggested Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Groves of big trees be set aside and created parks across the nation.  Famed for his park designs, Central Park in New York City shown above is Olmsted’s inestimable legacy to the nation’s largest city. “Olmsted had great faith in the ability of his landscape art to improve society and in particular to promote a sense of community in the rapidly growing urban centers of the country. His great parks and park systems were to be spaces held in common by all residents of their cities, places where all classes could mingle, free from the competitiveness and antagonisms of workaday life. His plans for residential suburbs, too, provided common ground that would foster both physical health and what he called “communitiveness”—the impulse to serve the needs of one’s fellow citizens. In addition, Olmsted believed that scenery could have a powerful, restorative influence. He was convinced that the spacious, gracefully modulated terrain of his parks provided a specific medical antidote to the artificiality, noise and stress of city life. In this and many other ways he strove to use his skill as an artist to meet the most fundamental of human needs in a comprehensive way. The psychological power of scenery, he felt, could be achieved in landscape design only through subordination of all elements to the creation of a single effect.”  He create places in parks with a conscious effort to express a "considerable complexity of light and shadow near the eye" or "obscurity of detail further away." The Olmsted Firm-An Introduction “From Buffalo to Louisville, Atlanta to Seattle, Baltimore to Los Angeles, the Olmsteds’ work reflects a vision of American communities and American society still relevant today—a commitment to visually compelling and accessible green space that restores and nurtures the body and spirit of all people, regardless of their economic circumstances. The Olmsteds believed in the restorative value of landscape and that parks can bring social improvement by promoting a greater sense of community and providing recreational opportunities, especially in urban environments.“ About the Olmsted Legacy Papers of Frederick Law Olmsted Olmsted to Charles Loring Brace, Brookline, March 7, 1882, The Papers of Frederick Law Olmsted, Volume VII, Parks, Politics, and Patronage 1874–1882, eds. Charles E. Beveridge, Carolyn F. Hoffman and Kenneth Hawkins (Baltimore, MD: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007): 592. Footnotes[1] Seven ‘S’ of Olmsted’s Design

How has the events of 2020 with Covid-19 and lockdowns made you realise the importance of nature and a connection with the outdoors? Let’s start by saying that I grew up with nature. I was raised to fish, hunt, camp, garden and keep in touch with nature. When I decided my spiritual path I chose Wicca - among other reasons, because I have an affinity for nature, and the Pagan way has kept me in tune with the planet for over 50 years. I cared about Mother Earth long before it was fashionable. Nowadays they call it ‘woke’. I guess I’ve never been ‘asleep’. Ok, now as for the ‘year in review’, having to stay inside because of the lockdown has been hard on me and a lot of the people I know. This was the first year in my life since I was 5 yrs old that I haven’t gone camping or swimming. I believe that the lockdown has hurt nature lovers a lot more than it has couch potatoes, but I’m hoping that they also have been affected to the point that they don’t ever want to see it happen again. All of us have lost people we loved. Therefore the next time something like this comes along (and it will) everyone needs to insist on immediate action from the powers on high to combat it. As long as I’m pontificating, one more thing. What’s even worse to me is the irrepairable damage done to the environment by the wildfires that are raging all over the planet. We’ve lost so many life-giving, oxygen-giving trees, from Australia to the Amazon jungle to the west coast of the US, that it will literally take a hundred years to replace. We’re going to need to breathe long before then. We’ve been raping mother earth for about 150 years now. It only took her ONE to start paying us back. And payback is a motherfrucker. “It not nice to fool Mother Nature.” 💀

Q: How has the events of 2020 with Covid-19 and lockdowns made you realise the importance of nature and a connection with the outdoors? A: Interesting question! Not for me, as I was already I think well connected. I retired some years ago to a small rural acreage. I go for a walk, run or bicycle ride through the (relatively) unpolluted country air most mornings and reflect how blessed I am. It has for others, judging by local real estate activity. Many are interested in getting out of the city. But this is also I imagine because of the increased opportunities to work from home and the increased awareness of it and its advantages. It is likely that as a result, more offices are going to work on a “hot desk” model where employees do not have dedicated workspaces at the company premises, with the many savings this brings. (It may be a bad time to be the landlord of these office spaces.) As others have said, the more profound impacts are interpersonal. See my page worth a read whoever wrote it. Perhaps this may even reduce the priority on nature and the environment, by increasing the emphasis on these other priorities. But hopefully not, ideally they are not in conflict.

Good question. The honest answer is I didn’t need a pandemic to appreciate how critical nature and a connection to the outdoors are. My experiences in our national park system literally changed the course of my life to a path I find much more rewarding than where I would be had I elected to continue my twenty- five years in corporate America. As for the impact of the pandemic, my wife is a doctor and endured tremendous stress during the pandemic’s early days. She’s come to rely on the trips I plan into our parks as a reset and a stress relief valve. When the lockdowns were all the rage, it was hard to find locations close enough for quick weekend trips. We also cancelled plans to visit Alaska in late June and replaced that trip by driving the length of the Blue Ridge Parkway and across North Carolina to the Outer Banks. In the end, our park time in 2020 hasn’t decreased much from what it would have been, though the destinations changed. The pandemic did change my wife’s appreciation for what I had done in completing my goal to visit all 421 National Park Service units, originally finished on December 8, 2017 when there were still 417 units. I never took for granted traveling to places like Guam, American Samoa or the Alaskan wilderness. Now, it’s nearly impossible to reach those locations. You never know when the window of opportunity to explore will close.

It’s confirmed to me the for the good of one’s peoples psyche, one should be a participant in nature, and not just an observer.
